content: The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" limits representation or advising of certain foreign entities. Compensation is defined as any payment, gift, benefit, reward, favor, or gratuity for services rendered. In the context of the "Revolving Door Act of 1996," compensation is defined as any payment, gift, benefit, reward, favor, or gratuity provided for services rendered. The terms 'government of a foreign country' and 'foreign political party' are defined in relation to the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938. The effective date for the amendment is January 1, 1997, with exceptions for individuals whose service ended before that date. SEC. 3. CROSS-OVER LOBBYING. The amendment to Section 207(d) of title 18, United States Code imposes additional restrictions on former executive branch officers or employees who knowingly attempt to influence members of Congress or legislative branch employees within 1 year of leaving their government position. Any former Member of Congress or employee of the legislative branch who knowingly communicates with intent to influence any Member of Congress or legislative branch officer on behalf of another person will be punished. Former executive branch officers are also restricted from influencing Congress within one year of leaving their government position. Any former Member of Congress or legislative branch employee who knowingly communicates to influence any executive branch officer on behalf of another person within one year of leaving their position will face additional restrictions. Former Members of Congress or legislative branch employees who communicate to influence executive branch officers on behalf of others within one year of leaving their position will face additional restrictions. Employment by the House of Representatives or Senate and knowingly making communications to influence executive branch officers on behalf of others will result in punishment as provided in section 216. SEC. 4. FELONS. Section 207 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit convicted felons who are former Members of Congress, former high-salary employees of the House or Senate, or certain executive branch employees from making paid communications or appearances before House employees. Convicted felons who are former Members of Congress, high-salary employees of the House or Senate, or certain executive branch employees are prohibited from making paid communications or appearances before House employees. SEC. 5 amends the Foreign Agents Registration Act regarding lobbying activities. SEC. 6 addresses civil penalties. Section 3(h) of the Foreign Agents Registration Act is amended to require individuals engaged in lobbying activities to register. Civil penalties for violations of the Act are increased to a maximum of $50,000 per violation.
